name: Server settings
description: These properties are used to configure Tolgee server.

children.name: server.port
children.description: Port on which Tolgee exposes itself

name: Data source settings
description:
Since Tolgee is built on Spring framework, to configure its database connection you have to edit following
configuration props. These properties can be omitted when using
[`postgres-autostart`](/self_hosting/configuration.mdx#postgres-autostart), which is enabled by default.

children.name: spring.datasource.url
children.description: The url of the datasource in format `jdbc:postgresql://<host>:<port>/<dbname>`. e.g. `jdbc:postgresql://db:5432/postgres`

children.name: spring.datasource.username
children.description: Database username. e.g. `postgres`

children.name: spring.datasource.password
children.description: Database password. e.g. `postgres`

children.name: appName
children.description: Name of the application.

children.name: authentication
children.description: Configuration of Tolgee's authentication.

children.name: createInitialUser
children.description: If true, Tolgee creates initial user on first start-up.

children.name: enabled
children.description: Whether authentication is enabled. If not, Tolgee will create implicit user on first startup and will automatically log you in. No login page shows, no permissions are managed. This is very useful, when you want to use Tolgee on your local machine, or you just want to test it.

children.name: github
children.description:
:::info
GitHub authentication can be used in combination with LDAP or native authentication.
:::

children.name: authorizationUrl
children.description: URL to the OAuth authorization screen. Useful if you want to authenticate against a self-hosted GitHub Enterprise Server.

children.name: clientId
children.description: OAuth Client ID, obtained in GitHub administration.

children.name: clientSecret
children.description: OAuth Client secret, obtained in GitHub administration.

children.name: userUrl
children.description: URL to GitHub's `/user` API endpoint. Useful if you want to authenticate against a self-hosted GitHub Enterprise Server.

children.name: google
children.description: The following instructions explain how to set up Google OAuth. [Setting up OAuth 2.0](https://support.google.com/cloud/answer/6158849).

children.name: authorizationUrl
children.description: URL to Google `/token` API endpoint. This usually does not need to be changed.

children.name: clientId
children.description: OAuth Client ID, obtained in Google Cloud Console.

children.name: clientSecret
children.description: OAuth Client secret, obtained in Google Cloud Console.

children.name: userUrl
children.description: URL to Google `/userinfo` API endpoint. This usually does not need to be changed.

children.name: workspaceDomain
children.description: The registration can be limited to users of a Google Workspace domain. If nothing is set, anyone can log in with their Google account.

children.name: initialPassword
children.description:
Password of initial user. If unspecified, a random password will be generated and stored in the `initial.pwd` file,
located at the root of Tolgee's data path.

children.name: initialUsername
children.description: Username of initial user.

children.name: jwtExpiration
children.description: Expiration time of generated JWT tokens in milliseconds.

children.name: jwtSecret
children.description:
Secret used to sign JWT authentication tokens with. It will be generated automatically, if not provided. You will be fine with 64 characters long random string.
Generated automatically, if not provided. If running multiple replicas, it's required to set it or otherwise you will be constantly logged out.

children.name: jwtSuperExpiration
children.description: Expiration time of generated JWT tokens for superuser in milliseconds.

children.name: ldap
children.description:
:::warning
This feature is experimental!
:::

:::info
LDAP authentication can be used in combination with GitHub or native authentication.
:::

Tolgee can use a LDAP server to authenticate users. This is very useful if you already use LDAP as a primary mean of
authentication for other services.

children.name: baseDn
children.description: LDAP base DN. For example `dc=example,dc=com`

children.name: enabled
children.description: Whether LDAP authentication is enabled. If enabled, you need to set all remaining properties below.

children.name: port
children.description: LDAP server host

children.name: principalPassword
children.description: LDAP password for the manager DN

children.name: securityPrincipal
children.description: LDAP manager DN. For example `cn=admin,dc=example,dc=com`

children.name: urls
children.description: LDAP server URLs. For example `ldap://localhost:389`

children.name: userDnPattern
children.description: LDAP user search filter. For example `(uid={0})`

children.name: nativeEnabled
children.description: Whether user credentials are stored in Tolgee's database. If you would like to use LDAP, set this to `false`.

children.name: needsEmailVerification
children.description: Whether users need to verify their email addresses when creating their account. Requires a valid [SMTP configuration](#SMTP).

children.name: oauth2
children.description:
OAuth 2.0 is the industry-standard protocol for authorization.
This enables the integration of a wide range of authorization providers into tolgee, such as Auth0, KeyCloak, Okta and others.

children.name: authorizationUrl
children.description: URL to OAuth2 authorize API endpoint. This endpoint will exposed to the frontend.

children.name: clientId
children.description: OAuth2 Client ID

children.name: clientSecret
children.description: OAuth2 Client secret

children.name: scopes
children.description:
Oauth2 scopes (as list)
Tolgee absolutely requires rights to view the email and user information (also known as openid data).
In most cases the scopes `openid email profile` is used for this. (But can also be different depending on the provider)

children.name: tokenUrl
children.description: URL to OAuth2 token API endpoint.

children.name: userUrl
children.description: URL to OAuth2 userinfo API endpoint.

children.name: registrationsAllowed
children.description: Enable/disable sign ups into Tolgee.

children.name: securedImageRetrieval
children.description:
Whether image assets should be protected by Tolgee. When enabled, all images are served with a secure token valid for
a set period of time to prevent unauthorized access to images.

children.name: securedImageTimestampMaxAge
children.description: Expiration time of a generated image access token in seconds.

children.name: userCanCreateOrganizations
children.description:
Whether regular users are allowed to create organizations. When `false`, only administrators can create organizations.
By default, when the user has no organization, one is created for them, this doesn't apply
when `user-can-create-organizations = false`. In that case, the user without organization has no permissions on the server.

children.name: cache
children.description:
At the expense of higher memory footprint, Tolgee can use a cache to reduce the stress on the database and fetch the
data it needs faster. Cache is also used to track certain states, such as rate limits.

children.name: caffeineMaxSize
children.description:
Maximum size of the Caffeine cache. When exceeded, some entries will be purged from cache. Set to -1 to disable size limitation.
This has no effect when Redis cache is used. See
[Caffeine's documentation about size-based eviction](https://github.com/ben-manes/caffeine/wiki/Eviction#size-based)

children.name: defaultTtl
children.description: TTL of cache data, in milliseconds.

children.name: enabled
children.description: Whether Tolgee should use a cache.

children.name: useRedis
children.description:
Whether Tolgee should use Redis to store cache data instead of storing it in-memory.
:::info
In a distributed environment, you **should** use a Redis server to ensure consistent enforcement of rate limits, as
they heavily rely on cache. For a simple single-node deployment, in-memory cache is sufficient.
:::

:::info
Tolgee uses [Redisson](https://github.com/redisson/redisson) to interface with the Redis server. You can find the
properties Redisson expects [here](https://github.com/redisson/redisson/tree/56ea7f5/redisson-spring-boot-starter#2-add-settings-into-applicationsettings-file).
:::

children.name: fileStorage
children.description: Configuration of Tolgee file storage.

children.name: fsDataPath
children.description: Path to directory where Tolgee will store its files.

children.name: s3
children.description: Tolgee supports storing its files on an S3-compatible storage server. When enabled, Tolgee will store all its files on the S3 server rather than in filesystem.

children.name: accessKey
children.description: Access key for the S3 server.

children.name: bucketName
children.description: Name of the bucket where Tolgee will store its files.

children.name: enabled
children.description: Whether S3 is enabled. If enabled, you need to set all remaining properties below.

children.name: endpoint
children.description: Has to be set to a service endpoint: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/s3.html

children.name: secretKey
children.description: Secret key for the access key.

children.name: signingRegion
children.description: Has to be set to a signing region: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/s3.html

children.name: fileStorageUrl
children.description: Public base path where files are accessible. Used by the user interface.
children.defaultExplanation: The root of the same origin.

children.name: frontEndUrl
children.description: Public URL where Tolgee is accessible. Used to generate links to Tolgee (e.g. email confirmation link).

children.name: import
children.description: Bulk-imports exported json files in the database during startup. Useful to quickly provision a development server, and used for testing.

children.name: baseLanguageTag
children.description: The language tag of the base language of the imported projects.

children.name: createImplicitApiKey
children.description:
Whether an implicit API key should be created.

The key is built with a predictable format: `${lowercase filename (without extension)}-${initial username}-imported-project-implicit`

:::danger
While this is useful for tests, make sure to keep this **disabled** if you're importing projects on a production
server, as trying this predictable key may be the first thing an attacker will attempt to gain unauthorized access!
:::

children.name: dir
children.description: File path of the directory where the file to import are located.

children.name: machineTranslation
children.description: Configuration of Machine Translation services.

children.name: aws
children.description: See [AWS's Amazon Translate](https://aws.amazon.com/translate) page for more information and applicable pricing.

children.name: accessKey
children.description: AWS access key.

children.name: defaultEnabled
children.description: Whether AWS-powered machine translation is enabled.

children.name: defaultPrimary
children.description: Whether to use AWS Amazon Translate as a primary translation engine.

children.name: region
children.description: AWS region.

children.name: secretKey
children.description: AWS secret key.

children.name: azure
children.description: See [Azure Cognitive Translation](https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/services/cognitive-services/translator-text-api/) page for more information and applicable pricing.

children.name: authKey
children.description: Azure Cognitive Translation auth key.

children.name: defaultEnabled
children.description: Whether Azure Cognitive Translation is enabled.

children.name: defaultPrimary
children.description: Whether to use Azure Cognitive Translation as a primary translation engine.

children.name: region
children.description: Azure Cognitive Translation region.

children.name: baidu
children.description: See [Baidu's](https://fanyi-api.baidu.com/product/11) page (in Chinese) for more information and applicable pricing.

children.name: action
children.description:
Whether the resulting translation should be changed according to the user-defined dictionary.
The dictionary used can be modified at [Manage Terms](https://fanyi-api.baidu.com/manage/term) (login required).

children.name: appId
children.description: Baidu Translate App ID.

children.name: appSecret
children.description: Baidu Translate Secret key.

children.name: defaultEnabled
children.description: Whether Baidu-powered machine translation is enabled.

children.name: defaultPrimary
children.description: Whether to use Baidu Translate as a primary translation engine.

children.name: deepl
children.description: See [DeepL's](https://www.deepl.com/) page for more information and applicable pricing.

children.name: authKey
children.description: DeepL auth key. Both key types (commercial and free) are supported.

children.name: defaultEnabled
children.description: Whether DeepL-powered machine translation is enabled.

children.name: defaultPrimary
children.description: Whether to use DeepL as a primary translation engine.

children.name: formality
children.description:
Whether the translated text should lean towards formal or informal language.
See [DeepL's documentation](https://www.deepl.com/docs-api/translating-text/request/) for supported languages and details.

children.name: freeCreditsAmount
children.description:
Amount of machine translations users of the Free tier can request per month. Used by Tolgee Cloud,
see [pricing](/pricing). Set to `-1` to disable credit-based limitation.

children.name: google
children.description:
See [Google Cloud Translation](https://cloud.google.com/translate) page for more information and applicable
pricing.

children.name: apiKey
children.description: Google Cloud Translation API key.

children.name: defaultEnabled
children.description: Whether Google-powered machine translation is enabled.

children.name: defaultPrimary
children.description: Whether to use Google Cloud Translation as a primary translation engine.

children.name: maxScreenshotsPerKey
children.description: Maximum amount of screenshots which can be uploaded per API key.

children.name: maxTranslationTextLength
children.description: Maximum length of translations.

children.name: maxUploadFileSize
children.description: Maximum size of uploaded files (in kilobytes).

children.name: postgresAutostart
children.description:
:::info
This feature was added in v2.
:::

Defines, whether and how is PostgreSQL started on Tolgee startup.

children.name: containerName
children.description:
The container name of the Postgres container.
This setting is applicable only for `DOCKER` mode.

children.name: databaseName
children.description: The name of the database created to store Tolgee data.

children.name: enabled
children.description: Whether to start PostgreSQL on Tolgee startup.

children.name: mode
children.description:
How is Tolgee running PostgreSQL.

Options:
- `DOCKER` - Tolgee tries to run Postgres Docker container in your machine. This is default option when running Tolgee using Java. See [Running with Java](/self_hosting/running_with_java.mdx).
- `EMBEDDED` - Tolgee tries to run it's embedded PostgreSQL which is bundled in the `tolgee/tolgee` Docker image.

children.name: password
children.description: Database password to bootstrap Postgres with.

children.name: port
children.description:
The port of Postgres to listen on host machine.
This setting is applicable only for `DOCKER` mode.

children.name: user
children.description: Database user to bootstrap Postgres with.

children.name: rateLimitProperties
children.description:
Configuration of rate limits.
By default Tolgee Platform limits requests to endpoints according to these rules:

1. Single IP is not allowed to request more than 20 000 times in 5 minutes
2. Single IP is not allowed to request public endpoints (authentication, sign-ups) more than 1000 times per hour
3. Single authenticated user cannot do more than 400 requests per minute

children.name: enabled
children.description: To turn these rate limits off, set this value to `false`.

children.name: recaptcha
children.description:
When configured, reCAPTCHA v3 is used to protect the sign up page against bots. By default, reCAPTCHA is disabled.

To enable it, you first need to [register a new site on reCAPTCHA](https://www.google.com/recaptcha/admin). Make sure
to select reCAPTCHA v3 when registering your site.

children.name: secretKey
children.description: Secret key for communication between your site and reCAPTCHA.

children.name: siteKey
children.description: Site key for use the HTML code your site serves to users.

children.name: sentry
children.description: Tolgee uses [Sentry](https://sentry.io/) for error reporting.

children.name: clientDsn
children.description: Client DSN. If unset, error reporting is disabled on the server.

children.name: serverDsn
children.description: Server DSN. If unset, error reporting is disabled on the server.

children.name: smtp
children.description:
Configuration of SMTP server used to send emails to your users like password reset links or notifications.

For AWS SES it would look like this:
```
tolgee.smtp.host=email-smtp.eu-central-1.amazonaws.com
tolgee.smtp.username=*****************
tolgee.smtp.password=*****************
tolgee.smtp.port=465
tolgee.smtp.auth=true
tolgee.smtp.ssl-enabled=true
tolgee.smtp.from=Tolgee <no-reply@tolgee.yourserver.something>
```

children.name: auth
children.description: Whether authentication is enabled.

children.name: from
children.description: The sender name and address in standard SMTP format.

children.name: host
children.description: SMTP server host

children.name: password
children.description: Password for SMTP authentication

children.name: port
children.description: SMTP server port

children.name: sslEnabled
children.description: Whether SSL is enabled.

children.name: tlsEnabled
children.description: Whether TLS is enabled.

children.name: tlsRequired
children.description: Whether SSL is required.

children.name: username
children.description: The username for SMTP authentication

children.name: websocket
children.description: Configuration specific to the use of Websocket.

children.name: useRedis
children.description: Whether to use Redis for Websocket events
